title: 103_hr1902
content: The Act may be cited as the "Buddy System Computer Education Act" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The Act aims to provide demonstration grants for public-private partnership programs that use computers to enhance learning outside the classroom. This includes developing skills like computer technology, communication, critical thinking, problem-solving, and teamwork. It also aims to promote parental involvement in education and family use of computers. The Act aims to enhance learning outside the classroom by promoting family use of computers and telecommunications, improving education skills, and fostering life-long learning. The Act aims to enhance learning outside the classroom by promoting family use of computers and telecommunications, improving education skills, and fostering life-long learning. Grant authorization is provided in Section 3. The Secretary will award grants to 3 States for computer-based education projects for children in grades 4-6 or middle/junior high school. Grants will be awarded competitively, with preference given to States with a commitment to technology education and projects serving economically disadvantaged students. Site selection and project implementation will follow. Site selection and implementation of computer-based education projects must occur within 9 months of the enactment of this Act. Program requirements must be met within 9 months of the enactment of this Act. Each State receiving a grant for a computer-based education project must provide a continuous 4-year program to consecutive groups of 4th, 5th, and 6th grade students or middle/junior high school students. Each student in the classes participating in the project must take part. Each State receiving a grant for a computer-based education project must provide a continuous 4-year program to consecutive groups of 4th, 5th, and 6th grade students or middle/junior high school students. Participants in the project must conduct it in up to 7 public schools within the State and ensure that each student has access to a computer at school and at home during the school year and summer. To receive a grant under this Act, the State's chief school officer must submit an application to the Secretary with required information. The State must assure efforts to match funds received, and there is no penalty for not providing matching funds. States can apply for assistance during a 3-month period determined by the Secretary. Grant funds will be used for hardware, software, and training for teachers, parents, administrators, and technical personnel. The Secretary will evaluate the program's effectiveness and report to Congress. The term "State" includes 50 states, DC, Puerto Rico, US Virgin Islands, Guam, and American Samoa. $4 million for 1994, $7 million for 1995, $5.5 million for 1996, and $3.5 million for 1997 are authorized for this Act.
